awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Organization of Rural Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to increase understanding of socioeconomic organization in tropical and sparsely populated regions. The research team will undertake research to study the relevance of settlement density in a lowland tropical region. Settlement density -how populations were spaced across the landscape- influences the degrees and nature of social interactions, which may result in diverse lifeways and forms of organization. Archaeology is well placed to provide relevant insight by focusing on the spatial and material components that are relevant to the notion of socioeconomic organization. Previous scholarship on socioeconomic distinctions has focused on class and status. This project provides an alternative approach by defining whether location in the settlement density continuum played a relevant role in socioeconomic organization. It will reassess assumptions of socioeconomic homogeneity and lack of large-scale integration within tropical societies. Results of this project will be incorporated into plans of local sustainable ecological and archaeological focused tourism in the region. Undergraduate students will be trained in archaeological methods.

This project will investigate the relationship between settlement density and socioeconomic organization. Specifically, this project will characterize and compare extended household groups in three settlement density classes (urban, peri-urban and rural). How did lifeways and organizing schemes differed across them? Does settlement density correlate with varied forms of socioeconomic organization?  Using a battery of techniques including remote sensing sampling, excavation of architecture and middens, material analyses, and sourcing studies, the project will study five material proxies in each sampled group (function of spaces, architectural energetics, specialized production, non-local items, and dietary patterns). If the materials proxies varied, it will be possible to distinguish these units based on location and settlement density likely played a relevant role in socioeconomic organization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This study shows that settlement density -the number of people per area and how they were spaced across the landscape- was an influential factor in the lifeways and organization schemes of the inhabitants of the Lowland Maya center of La Corona during the Late Classic period (ca. AD 600-900). Local settings influenced some activities in middle-scale settlement clusters that likely represented neighborhoods in rural, peri-urban, and urban density zones. This resulted in unique built environments and variations in spatial layouts and architectural features. Location in the density continuum also influenced some ritual activities and access to some resources, mainly lithics, plants, and building materials. This points to settlement density as an influential factor in access to some exchange networks, communal activities, and natural resources in the region.

The three settlement clusters shared similar organization schemes but were distinguished by unique sets of experiences. The characteristics of the peri-urban and urban settlement clusters were more comparable to each other and the rural cluster to other peripheral settlements in the region. The extensive dataset in this project show that rural settlements, however, were not less socioeconomically complex. They were venues for communal feasts that likely played important roles integrating elites in the region and helped shape the social, economic, and political landscape. This shows the importance of empirically assessing the individuality of each location. Furthermore, the notions of urban and rural lifeways based on shared experiences in different locations apply to the Classic Maya of La Corona. 

This study provides insight on patterns of socioeconomic integration in tropical and low-density regions. Despite some variations, the three settlement clusters shared various commonalities and were organized similarly. While this could potentially suggest decentralized and weak social integration in the region, inhabitants were tightly integrated through an economic system in which people had comparable access to a variety of local and imported items. Social status, however, played a role in access to some exchange networks. Combined data point to centralized and decentralized forms of organization, meaning that dichotomous interpretative models of settlement and socioeconomic organization that have been prevalent in Lowland Maya archaeology are not applicable. This study thus highlights the individuality of lifeways in each location without excluding perceptions of low-density settlements as integrated landscapes.

The results of this project also help overcome models that conflate social status and location. Specifically, elites should not necessarily be associated to dense urban areas and commoners to sparse peripheral locations. Despite its unique characteristics, the rural cluster shared many features with the urban and peri-urban groups. These include comparable subsistence and craft production activities, celebratory feasts, architectural features that fulfilled various functions, and venues for interactions of people of different social backgrounds including high status elites. This study thus distinguishes how some characteristics were a product of wealth and status while others were related to location, contributing to understand principles of socioeconomic heterogeneity in Lowland Maya societies.

Lastly, this project contributes to conservation efforts of natural and cultural resources in the Maya Biosphere Reserve by helping limit the expansion of illegal activities in the area. The local organization Asociacion Forestal San Andres Peten (AFISAP) will incorporate the results into its long-term plans of developing sustainable archaeological and ecological based tourism in the region. This project also trained undergraduate students from Universidad del Valle de Guatemala in field research, ground truthing lidar data, and archaeobotanical methods. It also provided work opportunities for local stakeholders and professional development for specialists and collaborators. 

 


Last Modified: 01/20/2024
Modified by: Jocelyne M Ponce
